review.title: PDDL2.1: An Extension to PDDL for Expressing Temporal Planning Domains
review.abstract: In recent years research in the planning community has moved increasingly toward s application of planners to realistic problems involving both time and many typ es of resources. For example, interest in planning demonstrated by the space res earch community has inspired work in observation scheduling, planetary rover ex ploration and spacecraft control domains. Other temporal and resource-intensive domains including logistics planning, plant control and manufacturing have also helped to focus the community on the modelling and reasoning issues that must be confronted to make planning technology meet the challenges of application. The International Planning Competitions have acted as an important motivating fo rce behind the progress that has been made in planning since 1998. The third com petition (held in 2002) set the planning community the challenge of handling tim e and numeric resources. This necessitated the development of a modelling langua ge capable of expressing temporal and numeric properties of planning domains. In this paper we describe the language, PDDL2.1, that was used in the competition. We describe the syntax of the language, its formal semantics and the validation of concurrent plans. We observe that PDDL2.1 has considerable modelling power --- exceeding the capabilities of current planning technology --- and presents a number of important challenges to the research community.

metadata.title: pddl2.1 : An Extension to pddl for Expressing Temporal Planning Domains

sections.text: The third competition (2002) presented the planning community with the challenge of dealing with time and numerical resources, which required the development of a modeling language capable of expressing the temporal and numerical characteristics of planning areas. In this paper, we describe the language used in the competition pddl2.1. We describe the syntax of the language, its formal semantics and the validation of simultaneous plans. We note that pddl2.1 has considerable modeling capabilities - exceeding the capabilities of current planning technology - and represents a number of important challenges for the research community.

sections.heading: 11.3 Temporal extent
sections.text: A common concern in the timeframes of argument discussed extensively by Vila and others (Vila, 1994; van Bentham, 1983) is the shared immediate problem. This problem emerges when one considers what happens at the moment of transition from, say, truth to falsehood of a meaningful variable. The solution we adopt is a combination of the pragmatic and the philosophically principled. The pragmatic element is that we choose to model actions as immediate transitions with effects that begin at the moment of application, thus marking the endpoints of the intervals that are closed on the left and open on the right, ensuring that the intervals interact without inconsistency and the truths of the proposals.
